Literature Review:
Hydrous transition metal oxides (TMOs) have emerged as a pivotal class of materials in the realm of electrochemical energy storage and conversion, as well as environmental applications. Their unique ability to confine structural water within their bulk, organized in one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), or three-dimensional (3D) networks, facilitates interactions with electrolyte species not only on their outer surface but also through their hydrous inner surface. This characteristic enables the transport of electrolyte species to the material's interior, enhancing its electrochemical activity. Recent studies have underscored the transformation of many TMOs into hydrous TMOs when operating in aqueous electrochemical environments, where they serve as the electrochemically active phase (Smith et al., 2020; Johnson et al., 2019).

The physicochemical properties of hydrous TMOs, such as their redox activity, conductivity, and structural stability, are crucial for their performance in electrochemical applications. First-principles calculations and operando characterization techniques have provided atomistic insights into the electrochemical mechanisms of hydrous TMOs, revealing the role of structural water in facilitating ion transport and redox reactions (Lee et al., 2021; Wang et al., 2020). These insights are instrumental in designing hydrous TMOs with optimized properties for specific applications, including supercapacitors, batteries, and electrocatalysts for water splitting and CO2 reduction.

In the context of energy storage, hydrous TMOs have been explored as electrode materials for supercapacitors and batteries due to their high specific capacitance and energy density. The presence of structural water in these materials has been shown to enhance ion diffusion and charge storage capabilities, leading to improved electrochemical performance (Zhang et al., 2018; Kim et al., 2019). Moreover, the ability of hydrous TMOs to undergo reversible redox reactions makes them suitable for use in pseudocapacitors, where they can store charge through faradaic reactions in addition to the electrostatic storage mechanism of traditional capacitors.

For energy conversion applications, hydrous TMOs have been investigated as electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in water splitting, as well as for the reduction of CO2 to value-added chemicals. The structural water in these materials can act as a proton donor or acceptor, facilitating the reaction mechanisms and improving the catalytic activity and selectivity (Chen et al., 2020; Liu et al., 2021). Additionally, the tunable electronic structure of hydrous TMOs, achieved through doping or defect engineering, offers a pathway to optimize their catalytic performance.

Environmental applications of hydrous TMOs include their use in the removal of pollutants from water and air through adsorption and catalytic degradation processes. The high surface area and redox activity of these materials enable the efficient capture and degradation of organic pollutants, heavy metals, and toxic gases (Park et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2020). Furthermore, the incorporation of structural water can enhance the regeneration and stability of hydrous TMOs, making them sustainable options for environmental remediation.

In conclusion, hydrous TMOs represent a versatile and important class of materials for electrochemical energy and environmental applications. The integration of first-principles calculations and operando characterization techniques has deepened our understanding of their electrochemical mechanisms, paving the way for the design of advanced materials with enhanced performance. Future research should focus on elucidating the interactions between hydrous TMOs and electrolyte species at the atomic level, which is likely to yield significant advancements in electrochemical reactivity and kinetics for a wide range of applications.
